Backdrop

The Backdrop

Cambodia was a French colony as part of Indochina. After Japan’s defeat in World War II, the French efforts to re-establish colonial control over Cambodia instead provoked armed nationalist resistance. This initiated the creation and empowerment of the Khmer Issarak (“independence”) force as well as the communist Viet Minh forces - the eventual Khmer Rouge regime, therefore, was influenced by a mix of communist and nationalist ideology.

After the First Indochina War culminated in the French defeat by the Viet Minh forces, Cambodia gained independence. The then-king, Norodom Sihanouk, came into power. During his rule, the Second Indochina War was fought in neighboring Vietnam; Cambodia was implicated, as it was used as a base for regrouping by both parties and was heavily bombed by American forces. Not only did this ferment anti-Western sentiments in the region, but it also continued the backdrop of instability and violence in Cambodia. Further, a civil war broke out in the countryside in 1967 and the Communist Party of Kampuchea (CPK) mounted a limited domestic insurgency.

Pol Pot, born Saloth Sar, General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Kampuchea.

It was within this climate of uncertainty that Prince Sihanouk was overthrown by his own Army General, Marshal Lon Nol, in 1970. Lon Nol’s coup was in part supported by the US military, which fed accusations of his being a US puppet, because he was anti-communist - something the US preferred to Prince Sihanouk’s neutralist stance. Lon Nol also massacred hundreds of the ethnic Vietnamese residents in Cambodia (then renamed as the Khmer Republic) and hence set a precedent for large-scale violence.

During this time, Prince Sihanouk allied with the CPK to regain power. The CPK was led by Pol Pot, an admirer of Mao’s communism. Pol Pot and the new leadership were very different from the veteran leadership; they were urban, French-educated and anti-Vietnamese extremists. The CPK, a guerrilla force, began to win on the battlefield against Lon Nol’s regime, as the latter became a brutal military dictatorship. It was mired in corruption and lost the support of the people. Pol Pot’s communism therefore carried with it the hope and promise of national tranquility.

HIST 2791 International Humanitarianism

This website is created for our team's final project, on the topic of documenting the genocide in Cambodia from 1975 to 1979 and its effects.
